content:
The bookstore, of course, was different than he remembered. He wandered its re-arranged aisles anyway, itching at his new (and excellent) haircut. In the week he'd been out, his clothing had begun to fit him better, which in its way had lessened the sense of foreboding he'd felt on his arrival back in town. Why, then, the lingering dread as he considered the picked-over Bestseller shelves, the pine tables with their CLEARANCE stickers, the supple thuk-thuk-thuk of the twin escalators (he remembered those well). Where once had sat four rows of Fiction and Literature now were bright pyramids of puzzles, board games, Lego; on the far side, near the bank of floor-to-ceiling windows, empty faded carpet criss-crossed by dark impressions where shelves had once sat.

Things he didn't know: 1. The name of the man he was here to meet; 2. The exact reason(s) (though here he had a pretty good idea); 3. What it was, exactly, he planned to do if that pretty good idea turned out to be the gospel truth. He was unarmed; no one knew he was here. A lot had to have changed since he'd gone down those twenty years before, but he knew all too well the trouble with assumptions, the flaw inherent in trust. Yet here he was. Alone. Free. And possibly, he knew, a liability.

And… then he died somehow. The Mafia did it. You all thought the Mafia was gone. Kill the Mafia.

...

Announcements, Announcements, Anoooooooounce, ments

1. Voting: Votes and unvotes must be in bold to be counted. (Ex: Vote: Dunhamganger.) You do not have to unvote between votes for the next vote to be counted. You may unvote at any time and need not specify who you were voting for.

2.Lynching: Lynches require a simple majority of votes. Once that majority is reached, a lynch is achieved and further votes or unvotes will have no effect.

3. No Lynch: You may Vote: No lynch if you wish to end the day without lynching (herp). No Lynch will also require a simple majority.

4. Deadline: This game will function on a cycle of strict 3-week days. Replacements near deadline will extend that deadline by a maximum of 3 days.

5. Deadline Lynch: When the deadline passes, if no player has a majority of the votes, the player with the most votes will be lynched. If more than one player is tied for the most votes, no lynch will occur

6. Night and Night Actions: Night will last for 72 hours maximum. Night actions not received within those 72 hours will not occur. Night actions will be resolved using Natural Action Resolution.

7. Lurking: Players who sign up in this game are expected to actively post and participate. Players who do not post for 72 hours without prior warning will be prodded. Failure to respond to a prod within 48 hours will result in replacement. Lurking will not be a viable strategy in this game and players who are consistently prodded or post only to avoid being prodded will be replaced at the Mod's discretion.

8. Out-Of-Thread/Beyond-The-Grave Communication: The game is not to be discussed outside the thread unless your role specifically states that you may do so, and then only in the manner stated in your role PM. Don't quote any out-of-thread communications regarding this game in the thread; this includes your role PM. In addition, once you're dead, you may post exactly once more (often called a "Bah" post) before endgame, and it may not contain relevant game content. Any violation of this rule is a modkillable offense.

9. Posting Style: Do not use odd colors, font size, or excessive images in your posts. Do not be unduly abusive to your fellow players. Do not edit or delete your previous posts. No codes or foreign languages. Failure to meet these criteria will result in warnings and/or replacement.

10. V/LA: If you are going to be V/LA, please post in the thread if at all possible. Do not assume that a simple site-wide announcement will suffice. Please treat this game like a commitment and respect the time and enjoyment of your fellow players.

11. Questions, Comments, Concerns: If you have any questions that need to be addressed outside of the thread, please PM me. Otherwise, you may get my attention using either of the following formats: @Dunhamganger, @Mod.

12. Playing to Win: If at any point I deem you to be playing against your win condition, you will be modkilled. No exceptions.

13. Catch-All: If you seem to be violating the spirit of these rules while operating under the letter of them, I will take appropriate action. Fair warning.

14. Fun: Having fun is by no means mandatory, but I would vastly prefer that each of you have some amount of it. If there's anything I can do to ensure that you do, please do not hesitate to let me know.

15. Modkills: A modkill will result in the day ending as if a lynch had occurred. Cool.

Sample Role PM:

This is a closed set-up. At least one player has the following role:

Dunhamganger wrote:Welcome to Bubble Tape Mafia, _________. You are a Vanilla Townie. You may post and vote during the day. You may do nothing at night.

You win when all threats to the town have been eliminated.

Day 1 begins. With 13 alive, it will take 7 to lynch.

Apologies for the large number of PMs this confirmation process required.

Given 12 other people, a random vote (assuming by a townie) has P=<number of scums>/12 chance of hitting scum, for example if we have 3 scums in total there is a 3/12=1/4 chance of hitting scum at random.

In post 1840, Dunhamganger wrote:P.S. I can't believe you cretins thought there was any chance kthx would retain his shots if he got blocked. For shame.
Actually, this IS how I deal with roleblocks.

Roleblocks stop the action from happening. The doctor never showed up to save the person, the jailkeeper never locked a person up, the vigilante never used their shot, the cop never investigated their target, and so on, because before they do so, the roleblocker stops them.

The roleblocker doesn't magically make the doctor's medkit fail, doesn't magically give the locked up person a key which leaves their cell vulnerable, doesn't magically grab the bullet from the vigilante after it's been used, doesn't magically destroy the cop's evidence before he's analyzed it, and so on.

If you want a non-flavor reason, NAR as I interpret it means the roleblock happens before the action--and therefore the action never happens. And if the action never happens, the shot is never used. Hence, it is refunded.

...Though this is a topic for MD.

Trackers, like a cop, would receive "no result", which is different from "x visited nobody" (or however the heck I'd word their target going nowhere), so they could tell just as easily as a cop that they had been roleblocked.

Edit: Oh, just realized what you meant.

If someone is roleblocked and tracked, NAR applies--since the block happens before the track, that means that stopping the person from performing their action happens before the tracker would see them attempting it. (Or in flavor terms...again, the roleblocker stops them from performing the action, and isn't magically sabotaging their action to fail immediately after it's attempted.)

In other words, the tracker sees the roleblocked person visit nobody, since they (when roleblocked) never actually did.

...Though that said, it kinda depends on the wording in the RB's PM.

If their PM says they cause an action to fail, it implies the action is attempted, but has a 0% success rate.
If their PM says they stop/block the action, it implies the action never happens.
